all magic hidden sub folders like windows thumbnail folders or desktop.ini files are only relevant for the desktop client and should not be uploaded as they have no meaning.

i agree with this proposed functionality. when sharing external data sources there is a need to be able to exclude hidden files. this should be made on the server, not the client side, so the administrator can decide what the user should be able to access.

for the sync client it might make sense to exclude some files from initial upload. should be configurable on the client, with some good os specific defaults. afaik the client already exclude some files from syncing. but if a file enters the owncloud than it should be easily visible, downloadable, editable, etc.
ok, good points. probably not a good idea to dive into that after all, and just display hidden files. @daveish thank you for your work nevertheless though! iâ€™m closing this hence.

should probably re-open this, or just hide hidden files by default (there's a good reason why they are treated as "hidden" files, i'd guess).

this is an essential feature, especially for macintosh users using webdav to connect. since they do not deliberately upload hidden files, but the operating system provides those desktop specific files when doing a server upload.

if it is relatively easy to implement hiding os specific files (i.e., if macintosh, then hide the files), specifically since the mac only creates very specifically named files (no os snooping needed, just look for .ds and ._.ds files, for example), and make it an optional setting within the config file (though default it to hide those files).

there's also still the issue of actually supporting reliable uploads from desktop clients as well, but that's a separate issue.

(i just discovered oc the other day, hence my reporting of issues)

ok â€¦ so we should not say this is a client issue, because there can be several clients. can we just have a simple blacklist of files which should be hidden? .ds and ._.ds files as well as thumbs.db come to mind. that would probably take care of 90% of these problems.

on aug 30, 2013, at 5:34 am, thomas mã¼ller <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> ok - these file got uploaded and i cannot see them.
> how can i remove them?
> 
the hidden files are associated with the actual files. you 'remove' them by removing the associated visible files, i.e. the mac finder / filesystem handles it. if you're not on a mac, this doesn't affect you.

> afaik mac os is duplicating the files in the .ds - right?
> there is some impact on quota as well.
> 

no, incorrect. mac files are composed of two components, files and resource forks. the resource forks are covered in the .ds components. this configuration has been around for nearly 30 years, so this isn't technically something new.

there is also a new file type, known as a 'package' file (.dmg or .pkg) which are seen by the file system as a folder, containing all related assets. this was the new, modern way of handling the resource fork issues in a manner that works across platforms, and is not impactful. 

the key to understand this is to treat folders with the extension .pkg as a file, not a folder.
i don't think a .dmg file is a package on a mac, but rather a disk image, which is something different again.  a .dmg file should be treated as a single file.

a 'sparse bundle' dog is treated as a package, a folder.
